Okay I'm like 90% sure that last example with Alzheimer's is bad science.

The researchers saw that people over 70 had less of that gene. Yeah because that gene causes some of its bearers to die before 70. This is not selection pressure though, because most humans reproduce long before that. The default expectation would be that there is no selection pressure on this gene, and this data doesn't suggest anything to the contrary.

The researchers then studied a younger generation and their parents, using the younger gen as a proxy (which is fine, they have 50% of the genes after all). Now they said they found a small effect but that it was statistically NOT significant. This is exactly what you'd expect if there's no effect and they happened to get lucky. Which happens all the time even if something is declared "statistically significant"! (see also: p-hacking).

Then we get to the theoretical basis behind why anyone might even think that a gene that only has an effect on people over 70 might be selected for or against...and that hypothesis is not very persuasive based on everything we know. There's very little direct selection pressure due to child-bearing people not being affected by Alzheimer's until long after they've raised the child. So the best hypothesis they can come up with is saying that the grandparents increase the fitness of the grandkids.

That is known by the technical jargon "Group selection" and we know enough about this to know that if it has any effect, it would be extremely small, and basically undetectable among noise in the data, which is also consistent with what they found, as mentioned earlier...

Basically, group selection effects are really weak because they drop off exponentially. A child has only 50% of your genes, and a grandchild has 25%. Something that helps you survive is twice as effective at spreading your genes as something that helps only your children, and four times as effective as helping only your grandchildren. Any impact on survival is diluted by a power of two for every generation.

And we haven't even started to mention the general uncertainty and chaos that comes with longer periods of time; not every grandparent ends up in a situation where they influence the lives of their grandkids. And especially in modern society where the current trend is moving away from multi-generational family units, this effect, if it ever existed, will only get weaker.

A much better explanation is actually seen here in some of the comments: with modern science people might change family-planning behaviour. If they have a family history of Alzheimers, or any other inheritable condition, they might be more hesitant to have children.

Regarding Alzheimer's reduction, there is the Grandmother Hypothesis. The idea is that the presence of a grandmother can make a huge difference in whether or not a child survives to adulthood. And it has been supported in a number of studies among poorer populations where childcare is often nonexistent. In those areas, they found that whether or not the father was in the picture didn't make anywhere as big of a difference as to whether or not a grandmother was present.

I think it kind of breaks down in modern first world nations (especially in the US and Canada) in some regards due to how we're encouraged to spread out and not rely on our parents in any way after we reach adulthood. But even here, there's tons of ppl who chose to move close to their parents when they have kids (especially when the kids are very young and the parents are inexperienced) for access to advice and assistance in childcare. And having extended family members that you can turn to in times of financial and/or physical stress can be the difference between life and death at times. My cousins on my dad's side of the family were all babysat by my grandma after school and when they were too young for school - and the same is true for their kids until Grandma died in 2018 (as in their great grandmother babysat them). This is so cool to me. I wrote a paper in my anthropology class about the variations in the human nasopharynx across different climates. Because our nasal cavities and the nasopharynx condition the air we breathe to match the humidity and temperature of our lungs, I hypothesized that the variations suggested specific adaptations to the air humidity and temperature that people lived in. I went a little further to suggest this could also be a factor in why our languages vary so much in how they sound. With warmer-humid air your vocal folds can be more flexible and produce a wider range of sounds, the opposite is true in cold-dry air. I think the evidence I cited for this was a paper showing how tonal languages were distributed along or near tropical regions as opposed to higher latitudes, but it's been a few years so I can't remember for sure. "45 Degrees hot." Stupid foreigners and their stupid Celsius... But seriously though, you should specify what measurement you're using, could be Kelvin for all I know. Honestly, I don't understand the fascination with Celsius beyond 100 degrees = boiling, and 0 degrees = freezing. Celsius is a less accurate measurement. Fahrenheit gives you nearly double the precision of Celsius without decimals - approximately 1.8x the accuracy. People are very sensitive to small shifts in temperature, why would you want to measure those changes in temperature less accurately on a daily basis? Beyond remembering that freezing (which is more often used in daily life than boiling, where I am) is 32 degrees Fahrenheit and that the difference between freezing and boiling is 180 degrees, it isn't difficult. If anyone is lazy, it's people who use a system that is less accurate just to remember something you could easily look up any time if you forgot it.

Where does the 1.8x accuracy come from? If the difference between freezing and boiling is 180 degrees in Fahrenheit, and in Celsius it's 100 degrees... simple math. My chemistry teacher once said that he prefers to use Fahrenheit to measure heat to Kelvin or Celsius, and he even studied in Germany. When I cook I don't put in or switch to a certain temperature, I set the stove to "high." When I'm cooking, it makes sense to use Fahrenheit because raw meat is cooked at round numbers (145, 160, 165) instead of 62.8 degrees Celsius for beef & pork etc., or 71.1 degrees Celsius (ground meats). There's just no point to Celsius. Personally, I'm interested in a system that freezes at 0 and boils at 200 if you want a happy medium, make it happen people!

What we see is variation and adaptation, which actually results from a loss of DNA from the population's gene pool since only certain alleles tend to survive in certain conditions. Bacteria stays bacteria. Humans stay humans. There is no mechanism that can add DNA to the genetic code to "evolve" an animal from one type to another. Mutations and natural selection operate against upward progress by removal of DNA and can never explain the adding of DNA that would be required.

I loved the video but I was hoping you would talk more about how humans are still evolving. This has been on my mind lately, here are my thoughts:

A big chunk of us humans don't quite fit in the classical natural selection model anymore. Survival in today's world looks quite different from survival a couple thousand years ago.
For instance, my life was saved by modern medicine before reproductive age; my genes would've likely killed me but now I get to pass them on (yay for me, sorry kiddos). I assume there are millions of people like me with not-so-top-notch genes that survive and reproduce who otherwise wouldn't, which leads me to think that we're... devolving thanks to modern medicine and ease of access to food and water.

There is still sexual selection but basically anyone with a lot of money can have kids at this point, and money as an attractive feature doesn't have directly to do with genes like strength or fitness (there are probably associated traits being selected for, which probably come from nuture, not just nature). A mate may be allured by money and willing to forego their sexual phenotypic preferences (not that that's a bad thing to do, money can mean safety and security). Or a female could pay for sperm donation (and there must be an equivalent surrogacy service for males).

Genetic drift will never be overridden but it's more powerful in small populations. There are 7.8 billion of us and we're moving around all of the time.

Also living in a safe, resource rich environment gives us a lot less need to evolve.  Obviously that is not the case for all of humanity, but for most people in developed countries there are very few conditions that require a genetic advantage to increase survival rates.

There is also some mild evolutionary effects caused by epigenetics patterns. It is not only a case of either having a "useful" gene for a given environmental set of conditions, but also IF it expressed and by how much.
Context is everything. Like those Ice fish in Antarctic waters that survive happily without haemoglobin -a condition that would normally be fatal.
Of course their is "somatic evolution" as well. That is evolution in individual humans, but remember that an individual human may last the best part of a century and be made up of trillions of cells. Thus in terms of pathogen-immune system relationships, and how cancers can develop aligns pretty much the same as ecological or evolutionary relationships at the macro level of populations of humans, or cats or oak trees.
So as we age, we all tend to be at increased risk of developing some sort of cancer, and we are not as good at recovering from infections and illnesses as we once were. Pathogens that develop antibiotic resistance is another example on the micro scale of things.
So if you come across an evolution "sceptic", you only need to say one word: "cancer". Of course, many cancers have both genetic and environmental causes, but no matter what the scale , it is still about populations of cells, individuals and groups of individuals.

I wish she'd talked about the evolution of skin color and how lightly-pigmented skin - i.e., "white" skin - is a very recent mutation that only occurred after the last Ice Age in some European populations.  Analysis of ancient genomes reveals that all modern humans were dark-skinned until about the last 10,000 years; remains found in Ireland that were only about 6,000 years old revealed that the person, who had been born and raised in Ireland by isotope analysis, had very dark "black" skin and hair, with bluish eyes.    When populations migrated to northern latitudes from Africa, dark skin would have created a problem with absorbing enough sunlight to produce vitamin D.  The problem would have been compounded by the need to wear heavy clothing to protect against cold weather.  Lighter skin would have been positively selected for in those environments.  On an evolutionary time scale, this is an example of recent and ongoing evolution.

Homo sapiens has existed as a distinct species for only 200,000 years.  In terms of population genetics, that isn't very long.  By comparison, the horseshoe crab has been around for 400 million years and the cockroach for 320 million years, so they have perfectly adapted to their ecological niche and have remained virtually unchanged for millions of years.  But humans are evolving both biologically and culturally. In 5 million years, we can expect that homo sapiens will have evolved new and unexpected traits, simply due to natural selection.  We might expect that the appendix, a vestigial organ, will cease to exist; that skin color will tend to blend toward beige; that the neo-cortex, the seat of reason, will grow slightly larger and more complex, while other areas of the brain shrink a little to accommodate that change; that our lungs will adapt to extract more oxygen from polluted air; and that the female pelvis will grow a bit larger to deliver big-brained babies.  But the big evolutionary changes will be self-directed, when we begin to engineer people to be smarter, more fit, and more compassionate, and then equip them with artificial intelligence and appliances to improve their powers of reason and judgment and help them adapt to changing environments, including those beyond this Earth.  Human evolution is just beginning -- unless we fail to grow as wise as our technology is sophisticated, which could bring the whole experiment to an ignominioius end.

The last statement is wrong. (Or potentially wrong.) There is reason to believe that humans are no longer evolving.

First of all, far far more people today are living to child baring age than ever before. So you are of an age where you can have children and child death rates are so low that it's a near certainty that your children will also grow to an age where they can have children. There is no natural selection going on.

Second, people around the world are self limiting their own off spring numbers. This is mostly due to economics and survival and birth control. Children are super expensive today and your children are almost certain to survive until adulthood so there is no evolutionary reason to have more than the minimum amount of kids. Women around the world are self limiting themselves to two children. No one is giving themselves an population advantage.

You cannot compare these cases with "real" evolution.
These are all very recent cases of gene variation and short time doesn't allows evolution to change the structure of proteins or enzymes.
In all these cases, genetic variation only modifies gene expression and regulation.
For example, the mutation that allows lactase persistance doesn't create any "new" enzyme, it just alters the expression of a gene that already exists and regulates the synthesis of an enzyme that already exists.
Presumably this is what also happens in the other four cases of this video.

This is why we should also be wary about genetic studies of ill understood conditions. For example, if there's genes associated with autism spectrum disorder, those genes might actually offset the deficits caused by another genetic variant.

Or the other way around. And that might cause some other imbalance, requiring a gene that changes potassium levels for example, since dietary potassium deficiency is commonly felt in people with autism.

Survival of the fittest actually reduces genetic diversity because the good characteristics become dominant over several generations.

Let's say that 1,000 years ago there was a "thing" that was fatal to 10% of a population, and there was no treatment for it.  People with the "immunity" gene to this "thing" would have passed down their genes more frequently, and people would have gradually evolved to a point where this "thing" isn't fatal to anyone anymore.  But take the same "thing" today, and we have a treatment for it. People who aren't "immune" to the "thing" just go and get a pill or an injection, and they are given "immunity" to it. There's nothing to stop them from passing down their genes, and those who have the "immunity" genes don't pass their genes down any more often. People don't evolve to be "immune" to it.  The more technologically advanced we become, the less we are driven to evolve. Of course, there will be other ways that we are driven to evolve that technology can't stop, and we will evolve.  But our knowledge changes how we evolve.

#4 doesn't make sense. None of the evidence presented here suggests the POE allele is actually being selected against, only that it decreases survival in later life. SciShow seems to be saying two things. 1: It's less prevalent in those >70, therefore it could affect survival. Agreed. It could affect survival in those OVER 70. 2: Those whose mothers lived to an older age are less likely to have POE. Okay. So people whose mothers are less likely to have POE, are also less likely to have POE. How does either of these two facts suggest POE is becoming less common? All #2 says is that if a mother has an allele, she is more likely to pass that allele on to her kids than if she does not have the allele. Nothing there suggests the allele is being eliminated from the gene pool. The only thing that would suggest it is something SciShow hasn't touched on: whether POE is less prevalent in their population of kids IN GENERAL through the years, compared to previous generations.

It seems obvious that lower frequency of a gene in the elderly suggests that it is causing them to die at a younger age, but I don't see how observing that lower frequency tells us anything about the gene being selected out of the population. Rather, wouldn't a signal of such a negative selection be lower rates in both the elderly and the young, with a higher rate in the middle aged? As a matter of fact, it seems likely that you could completely separate the two. Low prevalence among the elderly means the gene is bad for your long term survival, and low prevalence among the young means it is being selected against. It would be only when we saw both at once that we might infer that the CAUSE of the negative selection pressure is the earlier deaths that the genes caused.

I read a study several years ago (I wish I could remember where) that studied changes in skull morphology for modern humans (homo sapiens sapiens). The conclusion was that beginning about 15,000 and 10,000 years ago, with the advent of agriculture, modern humans began to select for more juvenile features, as we didn’t need the more robust skulls and musculature associated with a rougher diet. The result is dental overcrowding, but with a more juvenile face shape that in general our species and its antecedents have generally preferred. And then there’s the gene selection for dairy, also favored over the last 10,000 or so years with the advent of domesticated goats and cows. So, evolution is definitely an active (and here not so brutal) process.
